title: Can you categorize all human beings into seven specific types? - Quora

response.answer_text: Can you categorize all human beings into seven specific types? Of course I can. So can you. Anyone can. There are seven-point-eight billion people in the world. So the real question is, can we devise a typing system that can usefully guide us in how to deal with an individual whose type we know? Because I tell you, Myers-Briggs has 16 types, and the two ISTJ’s I know are nothing at all like each other. Their type is no useful guide at all. So I don’t see the use in jamming 7.8 billion people into one of only seven types, and pretending it tells you something useful about any one of them. No type would help you deal equally with the billion or so people contained therein, as if they were all the same in important ways. People in my experience are far more individual than that. They make and take exception to whatever generalities, boxes and labels, types and groups you try to draw around them or classify them with. We can come up with type trait boxes for groups of people and plug in those group traits for whoever we meet, but this is a very old invention. It’s simply prejudice: to judge in ignorance of the individual, in advance of knowing the individual. Usually by assignment of group traits. Sure, if you think fast and keep an open mind you can knock out trait after trait you discover they don’t have - but where was the advantage of the (stereo)type then? You could more easily and naturally have faced them with an open mind. Let them plug in the traits they do have, from what they actually give of themselves. Anyhow. It doesn’t strike me as something I’m likely to do, but yes. The answer to the question is yes. Of course I could. In fact I’ll go you five places better. There are two types of people in the world. You, and everybody else.

Probably not very well. Anthropologists have given up on racial classifications; there has been—and certainly is now—too much gene flow for it to work. Psychologists have had little if any more success with personality classification. Anyone claiming scientific credibility for seven “basic types” of humans deserves to be received with considerable skepticism.
